Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 54011-001 
Transaction Technical Assistance (TRTA) 
October 2020 
 
 
Republic  of  Palau:  Preparing  the  Disaster  Resilient 
Clean Energy Financing 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
 
The currency unit of Palau is the United States dollar. 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DRCEFF  –  Disaster Resilient Clean Energy Financing Facility 
  GRF  –  general reserve fund 
  MOF  –  Ministry of Finance 
  NDBP  –  National Development Bank of Palau 
  NDRMF  –  National Disaster and Risk Management Framework 
  PCCP  –  Palau Climate Change Policy 
  PPUC  –  Palau Public Utilities Corporation 
 
 
 
 
NOTES 
 
(i)  The fiscal year (FY) of the Government of Palau and its agencies ends on 
30 September. “FY” before a calendar year denotes the year in which the 
fiscal year ends, e.g. FY 2020 ends on 30 September 2020. 
 
(ii)  In this report, "$" refers to United States dollars.

I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  The  Disaster  Resilient  Clean  Energy  Financing  Project  is  to  provide  a  financial 
intermediation grant to the Republic of Palau to create the access of low income and female 
borrowers to affordable disaster resilient clean energy financing. The assistance is planned to be 
provided as a grant equivalent of up to $3 million to create the Disaster Resilient Clean Energy 
Financing (DRCEF) by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) and on-lent by the National Development 
Bank of Palau (NDBP). It will be ADB’s first-ever financial intermediation (FI) project in Palau and 
Pacific Developing Member Countries (Pacific DMCs) that targets exclusively disaster resilient 
clean energy financing available for low income and women beneficiaries. 
 
2.  The outputs of the project will include: (i) disaster resilient clean energy financing for 
eligible borrowers made available; (ii) accessibility to disaster resilient clean energy loans for 
eligible women borrowers improved, and (iii) capacity and awareness of stakeholders increased. 
The outcome will be consumers’ energy expenditures reduced.1  The impact will be aligned with 
(i) access to disaster resilient clean energy for consumers increased (Palau Energy Policy); (ii) 
safe, resilient and prepared communities for calamities and women livelihood recovery enhanced 
(National  Disaster  Resilient  Risk  Management  Framework);  and  (iii)  resilience  of  Palau 
communities to climate change and disasters enhanced (Palau Climate Change Policy).   
 
3.  While the ADB funding is a grant basis, however, it will be on-lent by the NDBP at cost of 
administration and risk premium, to provide affordable financing to low income and women 
customers for disaster resilient clean energy projects. Sub-loans provided by NDBP will be used 
by the borrowers for: (i) purchase and installation of energy efficient solar water heaters complying 
with disaster resiliency and energy efficiency (20% of loans funded by ADB FI grant); and (ii) 
purchase and installation of roof-top solar generation (80% of loans funded by ADB FI grant). A 
minimum 50% of all loans funded by the ADB will be used to finance low-income borrowers.  
Furthermore, at least 20% of loans funded by ADB and disbursed by NDBP will be to women 
borrowers.  
 
4.  The project will have a financial intermediation grant modality and is estimated to cost $3 
million funded by the Japanese Fund for Poverty Reduction (JFPR). The project will directly 
benefit 900 households in Palau, including at least 450 low-income households and 180 women 
headed households. NDBP will disburse 20% of loans funded by ADB to women borrowers and 
provide women headed households access to concessional financing. The direct and indirect 
project beneficiaries will make about 3,000 persons with household members of the borrowers, 
including children, ageing population and people with disabilities that are more vulnerable to 
external shocks.  
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
5.  The Palau government has taken some important steps to improve the country’s resilience 
to calamities and disaster risks. Approved in 2010, the National Disaster and Risk Management 
Framework (NDRMF) sets out a vision of “safe, resilient and prepared communities in Palau” 
harmonizing planning for disaster resiliency, risk mitigation and recovery measures integrated into 
national planning. The NDRMF draws special attention to women in livelihood recovery and to 
strengthening disaster risk management for local communities. In 2015, the government adopted 
 
1  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

2 
the Palau Climate Change Policy (PCCP) for Climate and Disaster Resilient Low Emissions 
Development with additional objective to mitigate global climate change by working toward low-
carbon  emission  development,  maximizing  energy  efficiency,  protecting  carbon  sinks,  and 
minimizing greenhouse gas emissions. The PCCP advocates a proactive approach to community-
level disaster risk management and includes specific interventions for: (i) funding support to 
expand the NDBP energy efficiency program through finance for constructing new and retrofitting 
existing homes; and (ii) developing, adopting and implementing a climate/disaster resilient energy 
efficient building code.2  
 
6.  The objective of the transaction technical assistance (TA) is to facilitate implementation of 
the project which is expected to create DRCEF as a revolving facility on-lent by the NDBP for 
borrowers for: (i) acquisition of purchase and installation of solar water heaters (20% of loans 
funded by ADB FI grant); and (ii) purchase and installation of roof-top solar generation (80% of 
loans funded by ADB FI grant). It is expected that at least 50% of all loans financed by the ADB 
grant proceeds disbursed to poor and low-income borrowers with a household income of less 
than $13,200 per annum by 2024.  
  
 7.  The TA will address technical matters of project implementation and will be attached to a 
financial intermediation grant for the project. The TA is consistent with the objectives of ADB 
Pacific Approach, 2016−2020 emphasizing the importance of expanding ADB work in climate 
change and disaster risk management to mobilize more financing for the Pacific region and to 
introduce innovative solutions to strengthen disaster preparedness, address vulnerability, and 
build resilience to natural calamities.3  
 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
8.  The TA is to support Output 2 and Output 3 of the project.  
 
9.  Output 2. Accessibility to disaster resilient clean energy loans for eligible women 
borrowers improved. The project will make significant impact on empowering women and 
improving women access to finance. The consultants will prepare: (i) a gender inclusive lending 
policy to improve accessibility to NDBP lending products for eligible women borrowers; (ii) set up 
a sex-disaggregated database in the NDBP for monitoring the project and lending activities of the 
NDBP with gender lens and impacts; and (iii) credit reporting procedures for all women-borrowers 
facilitating women’s future borrowing at lower interest rates and access to higher loan amounts, 
that will be a significant economic opportunity and empowerment for women. 
 
10.  Output  3.  Capacity  and  awareness  of  stakeholders  increased.  The  project  will 
increase capacity and awareness of stakeholders about the energy efficiency and climate change 
resilience technologies by supporting the NDBP to: (i) conduct extensive public outreach and 
awareness raising with national stakeholders including the civil society organizations and women 
from communities; (ii) conduct at least three nationwide workshops on DRCEF with social and 
gender sensitive participatory approach and minimum 30% women participants, (iii) develop and 
disseminate the communication and awareness materials tailored to the needs of women and 
low-income borrowers; (iv) training of technicians including at least 20% women as operators for 
installation,  operations  and  maintenance  of  the  rooftop  solar  energy  panels;  and  (v)  a 
comprehensive  database  of  all  installations  including  technical  performance  information  of 
 
2  Draft Palau Housing Policy (2019) includes a section on minimum standards for housing construction options including provisions 
for newly developed homes (e.g., standards set forth in the International Residential Code, 2015 Edition be satisfied, and new 
homes are designed to maximize energy efficiency, and produce and/or utilize renewable energy sources.  
3  ADB Pacific Approach is overall country partnership strategy for the 11 smaller Pacific island countries, including Palau. The TA is 
proposed in ADB’s country operations business plan for Palau, 2021–2023.

3 
selected  rooftop  solar  photovoltaic  systems  will  be  established  and  maintained  to  analyze 
performance of installed systems and monitoring of potential technical shortcomings.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $450,000, of which $400,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by  the  ADB's  Technical  Assistance  Fund (TASF  6).  The  government will  provide  $50,000 
counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office space, and other in-kind contributions. 
The value of government contribution is estimated to account for 11% of the total TA cost. The 
key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  ADB will administer the TA and will select, supervise and evaluate consultants, and 
procure goods. 
 
13.  The MOF will be the executing agency. The NDBP will be the implementing agency for 
the TA. The MOF and NDBP have experience and capacity in implementing externally funded 
projects  and  TAs,  including  those  financed  other  development  partners.  NDBP  previously 
implemented a pilot financing of $1 million for rooftop solar power generation development as a 
component of the cooperation with bilateral agencies.  
 
14.  TA will be implemented over a 24-month period commencing October 2020 and finishing 
in September 2022. Table 1 provides a summary of the implementation arrangements.  
 
Table 1: Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  1 October 2020 – 30 September 2022   
Executing agency  Ministry of Finance  
Implementing agency  National Development Bank of Palau  
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB  
Individual:  individual  International  (6  $103.32 
selection  person-months) 
Individual:  individual  National  expertise  $92.40 
selection  (12 person-months) 
Disbursement  The  TA  resources  will  be  disbursed  following  ADB's  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to 
time). 
 
Source: Asian Development Bank  
 
15.  Consulting services. The TA will require total of 18 person-months of consulting services 
(6 international and 12 national) in the areas of management and operation, finance, solar energy 
development, energy efficiency, technology and innovation, social, gender and communications. 
The  consultants  include  international  and  national  energy  experts  who  will  undertake  pre-
installation and post-installation technical verification in the field. NDBP will ensure that the rooftop 
solar photovoltaic systems installed adhere to the standards and guidelines established for the 
project.  
 
16.  ADB  will  engage  the  consultants  following  the  ADB  Procurement  Policy  (2017,  as 
amended from time to time) and ADB Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as

4 
amended from time to time. and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff 
instructions.4    
 
III.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to the 
Republic of Palau for “preparing the Disaster Resilient Clean Energy Financing” and hereby 
reports this action to the Board. 
 
 
 
 
4  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible in Appendix 2).

Appendix 1  5 
COST ESTIMATES AND FINANCING PLAN 
($’000)

Bank are presented in the table. The government will provide $50,000 counterpart support in the form of counterpart 
staff, office space, and other in-kind contributions. The value of government contribution is estimated to account for 
11% of the total TA cost.

b  This includes nationwide campaigns, workshops, and hackathon.   
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.

6  Appendix 2 
TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Technology and Innovation Expert (international, 2 PM intermittent). The expert shall 
have  the following  credentials  and  experience:  (i)  an  undergraduate degree  in  information 
technology, innovation, engineering or relevant science field (post-graduate degree preferred); (ii) 
at least 7 years professional experience; (iii) at least 3 recognized innovative case studies 
developed/managed, i.e. integrated solutions in renewable energy, water purification, electric 
transport, etc.; (iv) experience in organizing at least 3 hackathons on technology and innovation; 
and (iv) excellent communication/presentation skills. The expert should have established links 
with global technology and innovation hubs. A summary of key activities are proposed below: 
  
(i)  Review available information and Palau country’s assessments on renewable 
energy resources, (solar, wind, waste to energy, and other potential renewable 
energy resources), waste management, transport, etc; 
(ii)  Analyze Palau national strategy documents, programs and activities to capitalize 
the country’s energy asset and resources; 
(iii)  Prepare  Palau  country  case  study  formulating  key  issues,  challenges  and 
opportunities to capitalize energy by creating new economic opportunities for low 
income households and women; 
(iv)  Organize Palau country’s presentation at least in three technology hubs for system 
solution providers, developers and technology startups; and 
(v)  Design, organize and implement crowdsourcing campaigns like hackathons and 
open innovation challenges to identify and design early versions (prototypes) of 
innovative initiatives to address specific issues. 
  
2.  Energy expert (international, 1 PM intermittent). The expert should have the following 
credentials and experience: (i) an undergraduate degree in relevant engineering or science field 
(post-graduate degree preferred); (ii) at least 10 years professional experience; (iii) at least 5 year 
experience in design, installation and maintenance of rooftop solar systems, technical inspection 
and  performance  monitoring;  (iv)  relevant  project  experience  in  ADB  developing  member 
countries; and (v) excellent English written and communications skills. Specifically, the expert will 
be: 
 
(i)  Monitoring impact of the project and reporting on progress, issues and proposed 
recommendations;  
(ii)  Undertaking regular consultation with households that benefited from DRCEF 
facility borrowing for rooftop solar systems and energy efficiency products;   
(iii)  Providing  support  in  preparation  of  three  nationwide  campaigns  and  three 
workshops; 
(iv)  Supporting Palau government in raising additional financing for DRCEF facility, i.e. 
preparation  of  presentations  and  participating  in  meeting  with  potential  co-
financiers; and 
(v)  Preparing training course program and materials for Palau Community College’ 
graduates. 
 
3.  Banking expert (international, 2 PM intermittent). The expert should have the following 
credentials and experience: (i) an undergraduate degree in relevant banking, finance or science 
field (post-graduate degree preferred); (ii) at least 10 years professional experience; (iii) at least 
5 year experience in due diligence and financial analysis and modeling; and (iv) relevant project 
experience in ADB developing member countries. Work experience in Palau is required.

Appendix 2  7 
The consultant will undertake the following:  
 
(i)  Review of NDPB performance and lending operations, including but not limited to 
portfolio performance and risks;  
(ii)  Monitor progress on DRCEF facility funded sub-loans and preparation of quarterly 
progress reports to ADB and government; 
(iii)   Support to Palau government in raising additional financing for DRCEF facility and 
international roadshows at least in three financial hubs; and 
(iv)  Contribute in preparation of three nationwide campaigns and three workshops by 
NDBP for eligible borrowers and project stakeholders.  
 
4.  Social development (gender and poverty) expert (international, 1PM intermittent). 
The consultant should have a master’s degree in economics, gender, public, social development 
studies or equivalent, and at least 15 years of professional experience, including at least three 
completed poverty and gender assessment for banking and financial institutions under multilateral 
funded projects. The expert is expected to have a good knowledge of the Pacific region.    
 
Major responsibilities include, although are not limited to, the following activities: 
 
(i)  Review NDBP’s gender policies and assist to adopt gender inclusive lending policy 
in its operations and monitor implementation of Gender Action Plan (GAP); 
(ii)  Assessing the quality of existing reports, information/data generated by the NDBP 
from a gender perspective; 
(iii)  Supporting NDBP in raising public awareness of lending products exclusively 
aimed at women through performing following activities: (a) organizing special 
public campaigns; (b) conducting seminars on the use of gender indicators for 
decision making and product development; and (c) training NDBP’s employees to 
become gender champions, on gender inclusive lending policy, implementation 
and monitoring of the project’s Gender Action Plan; 
(iv)  Undertaking the project’s impact appraisal and monitoring in terms of social and 
gender development; 
(v)  Propose monitoring indicators for setting up a sex-disaggregated database and 
monitoring system set up in the NDBP for monitoring the project with gender lens 
and impacts and produce relevant sex-disaggregated reports; 
(vi)  Propose an efficient Grievances Redress Mechanisms to set up in NDBP to 
respond and resolve the complaints and issues of customers in timely, transparent 
and participatory manner; and  
(vii)  Conduct  a  training  workshop  for  NDBP  staff  and  stakeholder  on  GRM  and 
Problem/Complains Solving Approaches. 
 
National experts  
 
5.  Communication and coordination expert (national, intermittent, 6 person months). The 
consultant should have a bachelor’s degree in communication, social studies or equivalent, and 
at least 5 years of professional experience. The consultant should have relevant experience 
working for bilateral and multilateral funded projects on gender and social development in Palau.  
 
Major responsibilities include, although are not limited to, the following activities:  
 
(i)  Coordination of progress reports by international experts; including updates on 
GAP implementation progress and status;

8  Appendix 2 
(ii)  Supporting  NDBP  and  key  stakeholders  in  preparation  of  three  nationwide 
campaigns and three workshops;  
(iii)  Supporting  ADB  project  missions,  and  NDBP  in  implementing  GAP  and 
Consultation  and  Participation  Plan,  and  preparing  monitoring  reports  on 
implementation status of both documents; and  
(iv)  Under local publicity opportunities, explore potential outreach activity such as 
creating short clips/videos of the credit facility and beneficiary interviews (for 
example, showing the first solar rooftop system installed. The video material can 
also be used during succeeding public awareness campaigns and workshops). 
 
6.  Energy  expert  (national,  6  PM  intermittent).  The  expert  should  have  the  following 
credentials and experience: (i) an undergraduate degree in relevant engineering or science field 
(post-graduate degree preferred); (ii) at least 5 years professional experience; (iii) at least 2 year 
experience in design, installation and maintenance of rooftop solar systems, technical inspection 
and performance monitoring; and (iv) excellent English written and communications skills. The 
expert will support international energy specialist in the following: 
 
(i)  Monitoring impact of the project and reporting on progress, issues and proposed 
recommendations; 
(ii)  Undertaking regular consultation with households that benefited from DRCEF 
facility borrowing for rooftop solar systems and energy efficiency products;   
(iii)  Providing  support  in  preparation  of  three  nationwide  campaigns  and  three 
workshops; 
(iv)  Supporting Palau government in raising additional financing for DRCEF facility, i.e. 
preparation  of  presentations  and  participating  in  meeting  with  potential  co-
financiers; and 
(i)  Preparing training course program and materials for Palau Community Colleague’ 
graduates.
